Name: UTC2709
Title: Causality and Natural Experiments
Description: Introduction to the fundamentals of econometrics and establishing causality
Review: Took this module with BT2101 which also taught econometrics, be it through a more quantitative lens. This module provided greater insight and depth into the subject matter at hand in terms of why and how certain models in econometrics are derived and how they should be treated.

Name: IS2218
Title: Digital Platforms for Business
Description: A module taken to fulfil the requirement of an interdisciplinary module. This module overlaps significantly with my modules from my Business degree, teaching broadly the concepts across the spectrum of Business.
Review: Taking this module in Year 2 with the knowledge of accounting already at the back of my mind, I was able to breeze through this module for the most part, learning extra details about business platforms on the way.

Name: BSP2701
Title: Global Economy
Description: An introduction to macroeconomics and international economics, with a simple dive into analytical frameworks for real-world events.
Review: An introduction to macroeconomics with a little extra content added on top of what we already knew at the H2 Economics level taught in JC.

Name: FIN2704
Title: Finance
Description: A broad overview of the financial environment under which a firm operates (Topics covered: introduction to finance, financial statement analysis, long-term financial planning, time value of money, risk and return analysis, capital budgeting methods and applications, common stock valuation, bond valuation, short term management and financing)
Review: An introduction to time value of money and its variety of applications in a plethora of subjects to determine the worthiness of taking up a project.

Name: BT2102
Title: Data Management and Visualisation
Description: Provides practical knowledge and understanding of basic issues and techniques in data management and warehousing with relational database management systems, as well as data visualisation principles, techniques and tools

Name: BT2101
Title: Econometrics Modelling for Business Analytics
Description: Provides foundations to econometrics and the use of software tools to perform econometrics data analysis (analysis models, including regression, time series regression, dynamic causal effects among others)

Name: CS2040
Title: Data Structures and Algorithms
Description: Introduction to design and implementation of fundamental data structures and algorithms [basic data structures (linked lists, stacks, queues, hash tables, binary heaps, trees, and graphs), searching and sorting algorithms, and basic analysis of algorithms]

Name: CP2106 (Orbital)
Title: Independent Software Development Project (Orbital)
Description: Provides a platform for students to gain hands-on industrial experience for computing technologies related to students’ own interests

Name: UTC1706G
Title: Thinking in systems: Markets and Inequality
Description: Introduction to Systems Thinking and provides an analytical framework to analyse real world events in markets through the use of software such as Vensim

Name: MKT1705B
Title: Principles of Marketing
Description: Provides a conceptual framework to analyse and interpret marketing phenomena and to suggest courses of action in response to marketing problems (Topics: the marketing concept, the marketing environment and the marketing mix which includes product, pricing, distribution and promotion)

Name: HSI1000
Title: How Science Works, Why Science Works
Description: A module taken to fulfil the requirement of an interdisciplinary module. Hones the skills needed to negotiate a world in the post-truth era, derived from the scientific method

Name: BSP1702
Title: Legal Environment of Business
Description: Equips us with basic legal knowledge relating to commercial transactions so that we will be more aware of potential legal problems which may arise in the course of business and having become aware, to have recourse to such professional legal advice as is necessary in the circumstances (Topics: Singapore Legal System, mediation and arbitration to resolve disputes, the types of various business organisations for businesses to conduct effectively within the law, directors' duties & liabilities, the making of valid business contracts and the rights & obligations of traders in the market place and negligence in the business environment through misstatements)

Name: MA1521
Title: Calculus for Computing
Description: Basic foundation for calculus and its related subjects required by computing students, also covering simple mathematical modeling techniques and numerical methods in connection with ordinary differential equations (Topics: Preliminaries on sets and number systems, Calculus of functions of one variable and applications, Sequences, series and power series, Functions of several variables, Extrema, First and second order differential equations, Basic numerical methods for ordinary differential equations)

Name: ES2002
Title: Business Communication for Leaders
Description: Equips us with the business communication skills needed to be recognized as leaders among stakeholders – colleagues, superiors, and customers/clients (Core principles emphasised: audience-centred, objective-driven, and context-sensitive communication; intentional, reflective and mindful communication; oral communication fundamentals of verbal, vocal, visual and aural skills; and the 7 C’s of effective business communication)

Name: MNO1706A
Title: Organisational Behaviour
Description: Introduce students to human behaviour in organisational contexts. (Topics: Examining processes at the individual, group and organisational levels)

Name: ACC1701
Title: Accounting for Decision Makers
Description: Introduction to accounting from a user perspective. Financial reporting is covered from the viewpoint of an external investor. Book-keeping and preparation of financial statements are also covered at an introductory level.

Name: UTW1001M
Title: Sport and Competition
Description: A module taken in RC4 (Residential College 4) that introduced thesis research and writing as well as covered the various arguments and theological perspectives on sport and competition in today’s world - including functionalist theory, conflict theory, interactionist theory, critical theory and feminist theory

Name: IS1108
Title: Digital Ethics and Data Privacy
Description: Introduces students to the issues of digital ethics and data privacy faced by individuals and organisations. Addresses challenges in balancing technological desirability with social desirability while developing digital products and services, including Professional Ethics, Computing for Social Good, Digital Ethics by Design, Digital Intellectual Property Rights, Automation and Autonomous Systems, and Artificial Intelligence Ethics and Governance

Name: BSP1703
Title: Managerial Economics
Description: Provides basic working knowledge of contemporary economic thinking (Topics: market equilibrium, competition, monopoly, price and non-price business strategies)

Name: MA2001
Title: Linear Algebra I
Description: Introduction to fundamental concepts of linear algebra and investigated in the context of the Euclidean spaces R^n. Proofs of results presented in the concrete setting (Topics: Systems of linear equations, matrices, determinants, Euclidean spaces, linear combinations and linear span, subspaces, linear independence, bases and dimension, rank of a matrix, inner products, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalisation, linear transformations between Euclidean spaces, applications)

Name: BT1101
Title: Introduction to Business Analytics
Description: Provides us with an introduction to the fundamental concepts and tools needed to understand the emerging role of business analytics and data science applications in business and non-profit organisations. Students will learn how to apply basic business analytics and data science/analytics tools (such as R) to large real-life datasets in different contexts, and how to effectively use and interpret analytic models and results for making better and more well-informed business decisions.

Name: CS2030
Title: Programming Methodology II
Description: Explores two modern programming paradigms, object-oriented programming and functional programming. We learnt to develop medium-scale software programs using object oriented design principles and advanced programming constructs available in the two paradigms (Topics: objects and classes, composition, association, inheritance, interface, polymorphism, abstract classes, dynamic binding, lambda expression, effect-free programming, first class functions, closures, continuations, monad)

Name: STR1000
Title: Career Creation Starter Workshops
Description: The Starter Workshops are part of the Career Creation suite of training programmes designed to impart year 1 undergraduates with the core skills needed to prepare for their careers. The workshops take students through early and in-depth career planning and train them in the concrete skills necessary for their eventual internship and job search. The Starter Workshops comprise of the following: 1. Career Planning – How to Create Your Future 2. Personal Branding – How the World Knows You 3. Networking – How to Build Your Tribe 4. Resume Crafting – How to Impress on Paper 5. Interviewing – How to Showcase Yourself

Name: BPM1705
Title: Understanding How Business Works
Description: This module introduces new students to the nuts and bolts of the business functions of finance, human resource management, marketing and operations management. It allows students to have insights into how these functional areas work together for a business to function and grow. This module will take students through the journey of a new business from business idea conception to funding and commercialisation.

Name: CS1010
Title: Programming Methodology
Description: Introduces the fundamental concepts of problem solving by computing and programming using an imperative programming language (Topics: computational thinking and computational problem solving, designing and specifying an algorithm, basic problem formulation and problem solving approaches, program development, coding, testing and debugging, fundamental programming constructs (variables, types, expressions, assignments, functions, control structures, etc.), fundamental data structures (arrays, strings, composite data types), basic sorting, and recursion)
